com.stormpath.sdk.account

Class Accounts

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.stormpath.sdk.account.Accounts

  • public final class Accounts
extends Object
    Static utility/helper methods for working with Account resources. Most methods are factory methods used for forming Account-specific fluent DSL queries. for example: 
     Accounts.where(Accounts.surname().containsIgnoreCase("Smith"))
     .and(Accounts.givenName().eqIgnoreCase("John"))
     .orderBySurname().descending()
     .withGroups(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(50)
     .limitTo(25));
    or, if using static imports: 
     import static com.stormpath.sdk.account.Accounts.*;

 ...

 where(surname().containsIgnoreCase("Smith"))
     .and(givenName().eqIgnoreCase("John"))
     .orderBySurname().descending()
     .withGroups(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(50)
     .limitTo(25));
    Since:
    0.8

    • Method Detail

      • options

        public static AccountOptions<AccountOptions> options()
        Returns a new AccountOptions instance, used to customize how one or more Accounts are retrieved.
        Returns:
        a new AccountOptions instance, used to customize how one or more Accounts are retrieved.

      • criteria

        public static AccountCriteria criteria()
        Returns a new AccountCriteria instance to use to formulate an Account query.

        Note that it is usually more common to use the where method instead of this one as the where method usually lends to better readability. For example: 

         Accounts.criteria().add(Accounts.email().eqIgnoreCase("foo@bar.com"))...
        versus: 
         Accounts.where(Accounts.email().eqIgnoreCase("foo@bar.com"))...
        or when using static imports: 
         where(email().eqIgnoreCase("foo@bar.com"))...
        While all three statements are equivalent, the second and third examples are shorter and probably more readable.
        Returns:
        a new AccountCriteria instance to use to formulate an Account query.

      • where

        public static AccountCriteria where(Criterion criterion)
        Creates a new AccountCriteria instance using the specified criterion as the first query condition.
        Returns:
        a new AccountCriteria instance using the specified criterion as the first query condition.

      • email

        public static StringExpressionFactory email()
        Creates a new StringExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Account email property, to be used to construct an email Criterion when building an AccountCriteria query. For example: 
         Accounts.where(Accounts.email().eqIgnoreCase("john@doe.com");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's eqIgnoreCase("john@doe.com") method. This produces an email-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         AccountCriteria criteria = Accounts.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory emailExpressionFactory = Accounts.email();
 Criterion emailEqualsJdoe = emailExpressionFactory.eqIgnoreCase("john@doe.com");
 criteria.add(emailEqualsJdoe);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new email-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an AccountCriteria query.

      • username

        public static StringExpressionFactory username()
        Creates a new StringExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Account username property, to be used to construct a username Criterion when building an AccountCriteria query. For example: 
         Accounts.where(Accounts.username().startsWithIgnoreCase("foo");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's startsWithIgnoreCase("foo") method. This produces a username-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         AccountCriteria criteria = Accounts.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory usernameExpressionFactory = Accounts.username();
 Criterion usernameStartsWithFoo = usernameExpressionFactory.startsWithIgnoreCase("foo");
 criteria.add(usernameStartsWithFoo);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new username-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an AccountCriteria query.

      • givenName

        public static StringExpressionFactory givenName()
        Creates a new StringExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Account givenName property, to be used to construct a givenName Criterion when building an AccountCriteria query. For example: 
         Accounts.where(Accounts.givenName().startsWithIgnoreCase("Jo");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's startsWithIgnore("Jo") method. This produces a givenName-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         AccountCriteria criteria = Accounts.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory givenNameExpressionFactory = Accounts.givenName();
 Criterion givenNameStartsWithJo = givenNameExpressionFactory.startsWithIgnoreCase("Jo");
 criteria.add(givenNameStartsWithJo);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new givenName-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an AccountCriteria query.

      • middleName

        public static StringExpressionFactory middleName()
        Creates a new StringExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Account middleName property, to be used to construct a middleName Criterion when building an AccountCriteria query. For example: 
         Accounts.where(Accounts.middleName().startsWithIgnoreCase("Jo");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's startsWithIgnore("Jo") method. This produces a middleName-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         AccountCriteria criteria = Accounts.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory middleNameExpressionFactory = Accounts.middleName();
 Criterion middleNameStartsWithJo = middleNameExpressionFactory.startsWithIgnoreCase("Jo");
 criteria.add(middleNameStartsWithJo);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new middleName-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an AccountCriteria query.

      • surname

        public static StringExpressionFactory surname()
        Creates a new StringExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Account surname property, to be used to construct a surname Criterion when building an AccountCriteria query. For example: 
         Accounts.where(Accounts.surname().startsWithIgnoreCase("Jo");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's startsWithIgnore("Jo") method. This produces a surname-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         AccountCriteria criteria = Accounts.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory surnameExpressionFactory = Accounts.surname();
 Criterion surnameStartsWithJo = surnameExpressionFactory.startsWithIgnoreCase("Jo");
 criteria.add(surnameStartsWithJo);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new surname-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an AccountCriteria query.

      • status

        public static EqualsExpressionFactory status()
        Creates a new EqualsExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Account status property, to be used to construct a status Criterion when building an AccountCriteria query. For example: 
         Accounts.where(Accounts.status().eq(AccountStatus.ENABLED);
        The above example invokes the returned factory's eq() method. This produces a status-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         AccountCriteria criteria = Accounts.criteria();
 EqualsExpressionFactory statusExpressionFactory = Accounts.status();
 Criterion statusEqualsEnabled = statusExpressionFactory.eq(AccountStatus.ENABLED);
 criteria.add(statusEqualsEnabled);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new status-specific EqualsExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an AccountCriteria query.

      • newCreateRequestFor

        public static CreateAccountRequestBuilder newCreateRequestFor(Account account)
        Creates a new CreateAccountRequestBuilder instance reflecting the specified Account instance. The builder can be used to customize any creation request options as necessary.
        Parameters:
        account - the account to create a new record for within Stormpath
        Returns:
        a new CreateAccountRequestBuilder instance reflecting the specified Account instance.
        Since:
        0.9
        See Also:
        Application#createAccount(CreateAccountRequest)
